title: Jillian Michaels Inks Podcast Deal With Fox Corp.â€™s Red Seat Ventures, Joining Its Stable of Conservative Personalities
description: Fox Corp.â€˜s Red Seat Ventures signed a deal with entrepreneur and media personality Jillian Michaels making the creator-focused digital media compan
body:
Fox Corp.â€˜s Red Seat Ventures signed a deal with entrepreneur and media personality Jillian Michaels making the creator-focused digital media company the new production partner for her podcast â€œKeeping It Real.â€

	Fox Corp. this February bought Red Seat Ventures,Â a production company that specializes in managing content businesses for media figures including Tucker Carlson, Piers Morgan, Megan Kelly, Dr. Phil and Bill Oâ€™Reilly (some of whom are former Fox News stars). Earlier this year Fox News tapped conservative influencer Brett Cooper, who is backed in part by Red Seat Ventures, as an on-air contributor.
	

	â€œRed Seat has built a reputation for producing powerful, thought-provoking content with some of the most dynamic voices in media,â€ Michaels said in a statement. â€œIâ€™m genuinely honored to join the Red Seat family and bring â€˜Keeping It Realâ€™ to a platform that values substance, honesty and meaningful conversation.â€


	â€œKeeping It Real: Conversations With Jillian Michaelsâ€ was previously produced by Crossover Media Group. On the podcast, Michaels discusses topics centered around health and wellness with different guests, and the conversations span mental health, science, current events, relationships and work life. She brings â€œvaluable insights, inspiring life stories and actionable advice from leading thinkers, innovators and changemakers,â€ according to Red Seat. The podcast is available on Spotify, Apple Podcasts and Amazonâ€™s Wondery.

	â€œWe are proud to partner with Jillian and to be the new home of her celebrated podcast as she continues to tackle timely and complex topics while empowering and inspiring her listeners,â€ said Christopher Balfe, CEO of Red Seat Ventures. â€œNot only is she a renowned health and wellness expert but sheâ€™s also a motivator and an activist, and weâ€™re honored to welcome her to our growing family of bold voices and entrepreneurial talent.â€
	

	Among her business ventures, Michaels is the creator of the Fitness App, a winning diet and exercise app for women, and she launched Balance, a line of of fitness products. Her fitness DVDs remain the home workouts in history, according to Red Seat. Sheâ€™s appeared in multiple TV shows and is a regular contributor to outlets including Fox News, E! News, News Nation and Daily Mail. Michaels also is a best-selling author and public speaker.

	Her TV gigs have included serving as a fitness trainer on NBCâ€™s â€œThe Biggest Loserâ€ weight-loss competition series from 2004-11. Michaels recently disputed allegations made about her by â€œBiggest Loserâ€ alumni in Netflix documentary â€œFit for TV.â€

	In 2008, Michaels launched her company Empowered Media with business partner Giancarlo Chersich. Empowered Media is dedicated to â€œtotal-life solutionsâ€ comprising all aspects of living well, including nutrition, fitness, self-help and overall lifestyle.

body:
Playboy and Hefner Capital are partnering on â€œDead After Dark,â€ a Cold War-era horror-thriller set inside the iconic Playboy Club in Miami.

	The film will be produced by Cooper Hefner, managing partner of Hefner Capital and former chief creative officer and chief of global partnerships at Playboy Enterprises. Hefner is the son of Playboy founder Hugh Hefner. Additional production and creative partners will be announced at a later date. 
	

	While no cast has beenÂ announced, a source close to the production says that actors who top the wishlist for roles include ScarlettÂ HefnerÂ (â€œThe Vampire Diariesâ€), as well as Lukas Gage and Patrick Schwarzenegger of â€œWhite Lotusâ€ fame. As the feature is in early development, things could shift.


	â€œThis creative partnership reflects Playboyâ€™s commitment to introduce and build out our story-driven content strategy,â€ said Ben Kohn, CEO of Playboy. â€œâ€™Dead After Darkâ€™ is another step in a broader company effort to develop a connected Playboy entertainment universe, one that draws from the brandâ€™s vast archives, global influence, and consumer appetite for new IP. Weâ€™re excited to see how this first film resonates with audiences and to continue collaborating with great partners to develop additional stories across film, television, and emerging platforms.â€

	â€œâ€™Dead After Darkâ€™ is a love letter to both classic genre cinema and Playboyâ€™s legacy as a storytelling platform,â€ said Cooper Hefner. â€œOur goal is to create something thatâ€™s not only entertaining and emotionally resonant, but also true to the imagination and cultural curiosity that have defined Playboy for more than seventy years. Weâ€™re excited to deliver something completely original for Playboy fans that still feels unmistakably familiar.â€

title: SZA Has â€˜No Ideaâ€™ Where Nicki Minaj Feud Came From: â€˜I Donâ€™t Know Her. We Have No Connection to Each Otherâ€™
description: SZA isnâ€™t an artist who regularly gets involved in controversies, but when challenged, she will push back. That was the situation last summer when f
body:
SZA isnâ€™t an artist who regularly gets involved in controversies, but when challenged, she will push back. That was the situation last summer when firebrand rapper Nicki Minaj publicly accused SZAâ€™s manager, TDEâ€™s Terrence â€œPunchâ€ Henderson, of bullying her. SZA responded obliquely, but then the situation devolved into a back and forth too complicated to summarize quickly.

	SZA spoke about the exchange in the latest GQ.


	â€œI donâ€™t know her,â€ SZA said of Minaj. â€œWe have no connection to each other. Thereâ€™s no backstory. Like, there was no through line narrative. It was just like, â€˜Roc Nationâ€™â€¦. I donâ€™t know where it came from. Thatâ€™s not even my place to correct a narrative that I donâ€™t got shit to do with. It was a little strange. It was very like, â€˜Why?â€™ But also, you know, â€˜I guess.â€™â€‰â€
	

	Thatâ€™s not the only controversy she found herself embroiled in: Over the past year, sheâ€™s worked extensively with Kendrick Lamar, who is also managed by Top Dawg Entertainment, and found herself getting collateral flak from Lamarâ€™s ongoing, high-profile feud with Drake (which is even more complicated than the Minaj spat). SZA was quick to say that sheâ€™s friends with both artists and called the situation â€œunfortunate.â€

	â€œIt was something between two grown-ass men, so why would I insert myself between something between two grown-ass men, you know?,â€ she said. â€œAnd I feel like thatâ€™s how everybody felt â€” with the exception of people who didnâ€™t feel that way. I didnâ€™t really have any stake, per se. Obviously, I love Kendrick. Iâ€™m signed to TDE. Thatâ€™s my family. Obviously, Iâ€™ve known Drake for so long and we have a beautiful rapport. And, obviously, itâ€™s always unfortunate when the unfortunate occurs.â€

schema.headline: SZA Has â€˜No Ideaâ€™ Where Nicki Minaj Feud Came From: â€˜I Donâ€™t Know Her. We Have No Connection to Each Otherâ€™

title: Keith Richards, Mavis Staples, Norah Jones and Warren Haynes Rock Intimate Soho Sessions Benefit
description: Legendary soul singer Mavis Staples, age 86, is walking into the front row of the audience at the intimate Soho Sessions, leading a singalong on the
body:
Legendary soul singer Mavis Staples, age 86, is walking into the front row of the audience at the intimate Soho Sessions, leading a singalong on the chorus of â€œIâ€™ll Take You There,â€ the iconic 1972 hit she recorded with her father and siblings, the Staples Singers. â€œCome on now, now, yâ€™all!â€ she exhorts. â€œA little bit louder â€” take us there! â€¦ Donâ€™t you wanna go?!â€

	Iâ€™m standing by the bar near the side of the stage when someone walks up next to me to watch. I look â€” itâ€™s Keith Richards.
	

	He nods and gestures to the stage and says, â€œIâ€™ve gotta follow her!â€ The musicians standing with him smile sympathetically.

	Unaccustomed to reassuring a Rolling Stone, I say, â€œI think youâ€™ll be fine, Keith.â€



	

	



	Needless to say, he was. Richards then took the stage and led current Rolling Stones drummer Steve Jordan, guitarist Larry Campbell (last seen accompanying Bruce Springsteen for a recent â€œNebraskaâ€ set), keyboardist Ivan Neville and NRBQ bassist Joey Spampinato into a loose three-song set featuring the blues classic â€œKey to the Highway,â€ an acoustic take on his 1969 Stones showcase â€œYou Got the Silver,â€ and the Chuck Berry seasonal chestnut â€œRun Rudolph Run.â€

	â€œWeâ€™re done with Halloween, right?,â€ Keith laughed to the audience. â€œTime for Christmas!â€

	Moments like that actually happen at the Soho Sessions, the invite-only concert series that take place in a 175-capacity room in a Downtown New York commercial building that once housed the hip-hop mecca Chung King Studios (where classics by Run-DMC, the Beastie Boys and Public Enemy were recorded). The concerts, organized by producers Greg Williamson and Nicole Rechter, have helped raise more than $50 million for charity and have featured Paul Simon, Steve Earle, Gary Clark Jr., Taj Mahal, Yola, Susan Tedeschi, Brittney Spencer and many more â€” and on this night, an evening honoring actor-musician Bruce Willis to raise money and awareness for the Association for Frontotemporal DegenerationÂ (AFTD); Willis is afflicated with the disease. Norah Jones and Warren Haynes both performed three or four songs as well, in addition to Richards and Staples.
	

	In the audience? Demi Moore, Emma Heming Willis, Michael J Fox, Tracy Pollan, Whoopi Goldberg, Jeff Ross, Steve Guttenberg, Kevin Bacon, Kyra Sedgwick and many more. AFTD is dedicated to advancing research, awareness, and support for those affected by frontotemporal degeneration (head here for more information and to donate); previous beneficiaries have included Everytown for Gun Safety; Music Will, the largest nonprofit music program in the U.S. public school system; the National Alliance on Mental Illness / Hawaii (after the devastating fire in Lahaina); and others.

	In her comments at the beginning of the evening, Heming Willis said of her husband, who was unable to be present, â€œHe would have loved every moment â€” it would had been his perfect night.â€



	

					Photo: Dave Doobinin
	



	The sets were powerful but relaxed. Jones kicked off the evening, playing guitar instead of her usual piano. She noted this to the crowd and said, â€œI wrote this next song on guitar when I first moved to New York City and didnâ€™t have room for a pianoâ€ â€” and then broke into a warm version of â€œCome Away With Me,â€ the title track from her eight-Grammy-winning 2002 debut. Next up was Staples, who called Jones to the stage to sing with her on â€œYou Are Not Alone,â€ the title track from her 2010 album. After Richards, Allman Brothers/ Govt. Mule guitarist Warren Haynes closed out the night with a rollicking bluesy set.

	â€œThereâ€™s something sacredÂ that happens when artists like Keith Richards, Norah Jones, Mavis Staples, and Warren Haynes share a stage this intimate,â€ said co-producer Williamson. â€œItâ€™s nights like this that remind us why we built the Soho Sessions in the first place: to witness icons up close and let their energy ripple out into something bigger than music.â€

	â€¨â€œThe Soho Sessions have always been about creating moments of connection through music. Itâ€™s intimate, unscripted, and deeply human. This evening is especially meaningful because it celebrates a friend whose artistry and spirit have brought people together for decades. Itâ€™s a privilege to celebrate Bruce in this way and support the important work being done by AFTD.â€â€¨â€¨

	NICOLE:Â â€¨â€¨Â â€œEvery Soho Sessions is born from love â€” love for music, for community, and for the causes that move us. Bruceâ€™s courage and legacy remind us why we do what we do: to gather people, to celebrate life, and to use the power of music to make a difference.â€â€¨â€¨â€œThe talent gathered for this show is extraordinary, with world-class artists sharing the stage in a way that creates a moment youâ€™ll carry with you forever. Thereâ€™s a kind of shared energy in the room â€” a closeness between the artists and the audience that brings every song to life in a totally new way.â€
	

	Learn more about The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration (AFTD) atÂ www.theaftd.org.

schema.headline: Keith Richards, Mavis Staples, Norah Jones and Warren Haynes Rock Intimate Soho Sessions Benefit

body:
The Upside Down is getting animated.

	Netflix dropped the first look and teaser at â€œStranger Things: Tales From â€™85,â€ an animated spinoff of the streamerâ€™s beloved sci-fi series. Itâ€™s set between Season 2 and 3 of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ and features a new cast voicing the iconic students of Hawkins, Indiana.

	The logline teases: â€œWelcome back to Hawkins in the stark winter of 1985, where the original characters must fight new monsters and unravel a paranormal mystery terrorizing their town inÂ â€˜StrangerÂ Things: Tales From â€™85,â€™ an epic new animated series.â€
	

	Instead of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ stars Millie Bobby Brown, Sadie Sink, Finn Wolfhard, Caleb McLaughlin, Gaten Matarazzo, Noah Schnapp and David Harbour, â€œTales From â€™85â€ will introduce newcomers stepping in for their voices. title: Dark Spanish Hybrid â€˜Tonight Is Forever,â€™ Serbian Docu-Drama â€˜The Leaves Hang Tremblingâ€™ Take Top Honors at Thessalonikiâ€™s Industry Awards
description: Spanish directorÂ Fernando Souzaâ€™s dark hybrid feature â€œTonight Is Foreverâ€Â and Serbian filmmakerÂ Stefan DjordjeviÄ‡â€™s docu-drama â€œThe Leaves Hang Tre
body:
Spanish directorÂ Fernando Souzaâ€™s dark hybrid feature â€œTonight Is Foreverâ€Â and Serbian filmmakerÂ Stefan DjordjeviÄ‡â€™s docu-drama â€œThe Leaves Hang Tremblingâ€ took home the top honors at the Thessaloniki Film Festivalâ€™s industry awards Wednesday night.

	Set in the world of Tokyoâ€™s red-light district, Souzaâ€™s feature debut won theÂ 119 Marvila Studios Award, the top prize in the Agoraâ€™s Works in Progress section, offering sound mixing services in post-production. The Crossroads Co-Production Forum, meanwhile,Â gave its top honors â€” the Two Thirty-Five Co-Production Award, offering full post-production image and sound to a film thatâ€™s currently in development â€”Â toÂ DjordjeviÄ‡Â for the follow-up to his 2025 Rotterdam-premiering debut â€œWind, Talk to Me.â€
	

	â€œTonight Is Forever,â€ which follows an employee at a Japanese â€œhost clubâ€ who must confront his inner demons when his fantasy life begins to crumble, was praised by the jury for its â€œsubtle atmosphereâ€ and â€œstrong cinematic language,â€ with the jury noting: â€œWe felt connected with the emotional layers of this character in his pursuit of love. We were caught by the silence echoing loneliness.â€


	The top prize in the CrossroadsÂ Co-Production Forum went to â€œThe Leaves Hang Trembling,â€ which follows a teacher who is unjustly fired before her classâ€™s graduation day, only to have her students rally on her behalf. The jury praised the film â€œfor its unique approach to a deeply personal story that resonates with urgent global relevance,â€ adding: â€œCourageous, fierce, yet deeply empathetic, the film is profoundly moving as it puts children and students at its heart.â€
	

	The winner of the Onassis Film Award, which offers a cash prize of â‚¬10,000 ($11,500) to a Greek project participating in the Agoraâ€™s Crossroads Co-production Forum, went to the crime fantasy â€œThe Tide Hears Them but They No Longer Have a Voice,â€ from directorÂ Yiannis Veslemes. Citing the winning projectâ€™s â€œboldness and authenticity,â€ the jury praised a film that â€œaddresses one of the darkest political periods in Greece in order to speak about timeless themes and universal questions surrounding death and immortality.â€

	Other winners included â€œPromised Spaces,â€ an experimental feature by Serbian directorÂ Ivan MarkoviÄ‡Â set against Cambodiaâ€™s rapidly expanding cityscapes, whichÂ won the Authorwave Post-Production Award offering image services in post-productionÂ to a project in the Agora Works in Progress section. In theÂ Crossroads Co-production Forum, Spanish filmmakerÂ VÃ­ctor DiagoÂ won an â‚¬8,000 ($9,200) award for script development from Franceâ€™s CNC for his elevated horror film â€œThe Unmoving Hands.â€ The ArteKino International Award, with a cash prize of â‚¬6,000 ($6,900), went to Romanian filmmaker Andreea CristinaÂ BorÈ›un for her social dramedy â€œThe Life and Times of Ion G.,â€ whose producer,Â Gabi Suciu, also won the EAVE Thessaloniki Award, offering a EAVE Marketing Workshop scholarship to a producer in the Agora.

	Thessaloniki industry head Angeliki Vergou applauded the participants in this yearâ€™s industry event, praising their â€œsmart, courageous, political, funny, emotionalâ€ films, while festival director Orestis Andreadakis honored cinema as â€œan act of courage against silence,â€ adding: â€œIn times when voices are censored and truths are contested, storytelling becomes a form of resistance.â€

	Festival general director Elise Jalladeau, meanwhile, took a moment to acknowledge the perils of a world â€œwhich is at best in crisis â€” political, economic, environmental â€” and at worst engulfed in bloodbaths and massacres we call war,â€ noting that â€œculture is not spared from the crisis.â€Â 

	â€œWe are witnessing reductions and severe cuts in cultural budgets all over Europe, and it is feared this trend will continue,â€ she said. â€œFragilityï»¿Â is one of the themes of this yearâ€™s festival, and we are more than aware of it here. But this fragility is not fate, and we believe in the power of collaborations and co-productions to invent together new ways of making cinema.â€Â 
	

	Hereâ€™s the complete list of winners of the Thessaloniki Film Festivalâ€™s Agora awards:Â Â 

	Agora Works in Progress AwardsÂ Â 

	119 Marvila Studios Award: â€œTonight Is Forever,â€Â Fernando Souza

	Authorwave Post-Production Award: â€œPromised Spaces,â€ IvanÂ MarkoviÄ‡

	ERT Agora Works in Progress Award: â€œWays to Get Rid of Some Freedom,â€Â Chrisanthos Margonis

	Crossroads Co-Production Forum AwardsÂ Â 

	Two Thirty-Five Award:Â â€œThe Leaves Hang Trembling,â€Â Stefan DjordjeviÄ‡

	CNC Award: â€œThe Unmoving Hands,â€ Victor DiagoÂ Â 

	ArteKino International Award: â€œThe Life and Times of Ion G.,â€ Andreea CristinaÂ BorÈ›un

	Finos Film Award: â€œPirateland,â€Â Stavros Petropoulos

	Producersâ€™ Network â€“ MarchÃ© du Film Award:Â Fahriye Ismayilova, â€œGoodbye For Nowâ€

	Midpoint Consulting Award: â€œThe Dictatorâ€™s Dream,â€ Erenik BeqiriÂ Â 

	Independent Awards

	Onassis Film Award:Â â€œThe Tide Hears Them but They No Longer Have a Voice,â€Â Yiannis Veslemes

	Greener Screen Award: â€œA Girl Named Zeus,â€Â Nikos Dayandas

	Sofia Meetings Award: â€œRobbing Beirut,â€Â Katia Jarjoura

	Mediterranean Film Institute Award: â€œLa Forma Animal,â€Â Isa Luengo and Sofia Esteve

	Thessaloniki EAVE Marketing Workshop Scholarship: Gabi Suciu, â€œThe Life and Times of Ion G.â€Â Â 

	Agora Series Talents Award

	Crew United Prize:Â Katerina PapanastasiouÂ

title: Wordle Launches â€˜Create Your Wordle Puzzleâ€™ Feature From New York Times Games â€” Minus Certain Words (EXCLUSIVE)
description: The world of Wordle is expanding: The New York Times Games is launching a â€œCreate Your Wordle Puzzleâ€ feature that will allow users to go beyond jus
body:
The world of Wordle is expanding: The New York Times Games is launching a â€œCreate Your Wordle Puzzleâ€ feature that will allow users to go beyond just playing the popular word game, and instead develop their own one-word challenges.

	Debuting Thursday, Create Your Wordle Puzzle will let All Access and Games subscribers â€œturn inside jokes, special moments, or personal messagesâ€ into a 4-7 letter solution with a â€œcreated byâ€ label and an optional clue, all done via the New York Times Games app on iOS and Android, as well as mobile web and desktop.
	

	However, not every word can be Wordled.


	Per the New York Times Gamesâ€™ acceptable use policy for Create Your Wordle Puzzle, users are prohibited from including the following in their customized puzzles: name-calling, personal attacks, slurs, harassment, threats, hate speech, bullying, abuse, malicious acts, descriptions of violence or gore, and discrimination, as well as profanity (including expletives and letters followed by dashes that could translate to an expletive) and content that is sexual, salacious, obscene, or predatory, including grooming behaviors.

	The new Wordle offering comes at a time of continuous growth for the NYT Games division. In Q3, helped by its exclusive games lineup, the New York Times added 460,000 net digital-only subscribers, bringing the total to 12.33 million.

	â€œThe Games team has wanted to do this for some time,â€ The New York Times Games chief Jonathan Knight told Variety. â€œWe also talk to our users regularly, and take their temperature on what theyâ€™d like to see from us. And now that Wordle has a collection of great features surrounding it, like the Wordle Archive of over 1500 puzzles, plus WordleBotâ€™s post-game analysis, we knew the time was right to deliver Create Your Wordle Puzzle.â€
	

	Once a Create Your Wordle Puzzle is crafted, the creator will receive a unique URL that will let them share the custom puzzle with others. Notably, this feature allows non-subscribers to play puzzles created by subscribers.

	â€œWe think thereâ€™s a lot of value in the creation part of the experience, and understand that our most dedicated fans are the most likely to be the Create Your Wordle Puzzle makers,â€ Knight said. â€œBut we also want as many people as possible within those fansâ€™ networks (big or small) to enjoy the solving side of that same experience. This will make it the most satisfying for everyone.â€

	At this time, Knight says the NYT Games team is â€œnot lookingâ€ at creating custom versions of its other products â€” which include the Crossword, Connections, Spelling Bee, Pips and more games â€” and is instead focused on the Create Your Wordle launch. â€œItâ€™s just the beginning, and weâ€™re excited to learn and to see what people create!â€ Knight said.

	To coincide with the launch of Create Your Wordle Puzzle, The New York Times curated the below list of custom puzzles from nine prominent NYT staffers across the newsroom and verticals including Audio, Cooking, Games, Wirecutter and The Athletic:

	Melissa Clark, food columnist for New York Times Cooking.

	Play Clarkâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œGood to know how to make in a pan.â€

	Anna Martin, host of the â€œModern Loveâ€ podcast.

	Play Martinâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œA scary way to stop seeing someone.â€

	Ben Frumin, editor-in-chief of Wirecutter.

	Play Fruminâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œNext season weâ€™re winning it all!!â€

	Dianna Russini, senior NFL insider for The Athletic.

	Play Russiniâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œWhat I do while chasing news (and my kids).â€

	Marc Lacey, managing editor of The New York Times.

	Play Laceyâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œBring a camera and wide-brimmed hat.â€

	David Marchese, journalist and co-host of â€œThe Interviewâ€ podcast.

	Play Marcheseâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œItâ€™s what Iâ€™m often doing at work.â€

	Vaughn Vreeland, writer and host of â€œBake Timeâ€ for New York Times Cooking.

	Play Vreelandâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œA type of kitchen tool thatâ€™s handy for baking.â€
	

	Jacqueline Yue, product director of New York Times Games.

	Play Yueâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œğŸ§–ğŸ«§â€

	David Ornstein, football correspondent for The Athletic.

	Play Ornsteinâ€™s Wordle puzzle here.

	Clue: â€œThe element for which I have become most renowned.â€

title: Sarah Snook Kidnapping Thriller â€˜All Her Faultâ€™ Is a Middling Entry in the Rich Mom Mystery Genre: TV Review
description: Marissa Irvine, the protagonist of the Peacock thriller â€œAll Her Fault,â€ bears a superficial resemblance to Siobhan Roy. For one thing, both charact
body:
Marissa Irvine, the protagonist of the Peacock thriller â€œAll Her Fault,â€ bears a superficial resemblance to Siobhan Roy. For one thing, both characters are played by Sarah Snook, the Australian actor who broke out as the ambitious, oblivious heiress on â€œSuccession.â€ Both women are wealthy, although Marissa â€”Â a wealth manager based in Chicago â€” is self-made. Both favor a quietly luxurious wardrobe heavy on tasteful neutrals and cocoon-like outerwear.
	

	But the similarities end there. Marissa is defined by her motherhood, a phase of life Shiv was only beginning to contemplate at the end of â€œSuccession.â€ The series, adapted by creator Megan Gallagher from the 2021 novel by Andrea Mara, begins when Marissa tries to pick up her 5-year-old son Milo (Duke McCloud) from a playdate, only to realize he isnâ€™t there. What follows is a kidnapping drama thatâ€™s every parentâ€™s worst nightmare â€”Â although for a performer like Snook, who executive produces her first series- leading turn after the HBO hit wound down two and a half years ago, itâ€™s a custom-built showcase. â€œAll Her Faultâ€ (not to be confused with â€œAllâ€™s Fair,â€ the other female-focused hour with â€œAllâ€ in the name to debut this week) does allow Snook to emote with all her might, sobbing with panic and gasping in horror as Marissaâ€™s quest to find Milo takes its inevitable twists and turns. Yet the laboriously paced, clunkily plotted series canâ€™t hold a candle to Snookâ€™s most famous role, and seems unlikely to replace it as her signature.


	â€œAll Her Faultâ€ is another entry in the â€œBig Little Liesâ€ school of mysteries centered on wealthy women that mix conspicuous consumption with attempted social commentary. When Marissa runs through her house, frantically searching for Milo, the scene doubles as a tour of the Irvinesâ€™ palatial lakefront home as captured by directors Minkie Spiro and Kate Dennis. (â€œAll Her Faultâ€ was filmed in Australia; the ample outdoor space is a dead giveaway it wasnâ€™t actually made in a place with Midwestern winters.) Jake Lacy, who plays Marissaâ€™s husband Peter, also starred as a finance bro in â€œApples Never Fall,â€ another Peacock production based on a novel by â€œBig Little Liesâ€ author Liane Moriarty. Rich families, buried secrets, the gender dynamics of heterosexual marriage: Gangâ€™s all here!
	

	â€œBig Little Liesâ€ sets a sky-high bar, of course. But even â€œApples Never Fallâ€ had a breeziness thatâ€™s sorely lacking in â€œAll Her Fault,â€ which doesnâ€™t land any incisive points about parenting, class, codependency or hired child care but does get bogged down trying to make them. With the help of the lead detective assigned to their case (Michael PeÃ±a), the Irvines quickly deduce that Milo was likely abducted by Carrie Finch (Sophia Lillis), the 21-year-old nanny of Marissaâ€™s new friend Jenny (Dakota Fanning), a publishing executive. Carrie, a pseudonym, makes no ransom demands, forcing the Irvines to search for her motive by scrutinizing the people around them: Jakeâ€™s siblings Lia (Abby Elliott), a hotheaded free spirit, and Brian (Daniel Monks), who was disabled in a childhood accident; Marissaâ€™s best friend and business partner Colin (Jay Ellis); Jenny, visibly wracked with guilt; and even their own nanny Ana (Kartiah Vergara), whoâ€™s out of town when Milo goes missing and mysteriously left her phone behind.

	The anxiety of inviting another person into your intimate family life, especially a less fortunate one who might covet some of your hard-won comfort, has driven previous thrillers like â€œThe Hand That Rocks the Cradleâ€ (and its recent straight-to-Hulu remake). Thereâ€™s no reason â€œAll Her Faultâ€ couldnâ€™t update this repressed paranoia for the having-it-all age, and for a few episodes, it tries to. The title refers to the blame placed on working women tacitly assigned responsibility for their kids as well as their jobs, an assumption that becomes explicit in a time of crisis. Peter faults Marissa for failing to check that the phone number used to propose the playdate matched Jennyâ€™s listed one in their schoolâ€™s parent handbook; Jennyâ€™s husband Richie (Thomas Cocquerel), faults her for not double-checking Carrieâ€™s references.Â 

	It goes without saying that these couplesâ€™ employees donâ€™t get such an in-depth exploration of their own plight â€”Â Carrie because she has to remain an enigma until the end, Ana because the show simply isnâ€™t that interested in what makes her tick. Fair enough, but as â€œAll Her Faultâ€ delves deeper into the two primary marriages, both Peter and Richie come off as cartoonishly awful. The former is a control freak whose obsessiveness extends to the people he loves; the latter is a man-child who demands â€œme timeâ€ at the expense of Jennyâ€™s professional obligations. The asymmetry between them and their well-meaning wives is so extreme it saps the takedowns of any satisfying bite. The proper counterpoint to â€œAll Her Faultâ€ is not that, really, itâ€™s just all his fault.
	

	The silliness of this analysis could at least be matched by a silliness in tone. But the middle stretch of â€œAll Her Faultâ€ is slow and somber, especially a detour into the PeÃ±a characterâ€™s home life as he works the case. And when the reveals finally arrive, in rapid succession and with little room to breathe, theyâ€™re often out of left field. This is especially true when it comes to the central question of why Carrie has taken Milo, which hinges on a vital piece of backstory thatâ€™s been withheld for so long it feels both deceptive and random.Â 

	What â€œAll Her Faultâ€ makes room for by crowding such pivotal elements to its periphery is many, many scenes of Marissa in acute distress. Snook shines moment to moment; of course she does â€”Â she filmed the show in between the West End and Broadway productions of â€œThe Picture of Dorian Gray,â€ in which she commanded entire theaters alone on a stage and picked up both an Olivier and a Tony. But in the aggregate, Marissa is a bit fuzzy. I ended the series knowing little about her besides her devotion to her son, because Iâ€™d mostly watched her endure the worst moments of her life at the hands of other people. Itâ€™s not fair to say a womanâ€™s problems are all her fault, but at least that sentiment affords her some agency.

	All eight episodes of â€œAll Her Faultâ€ are now streaming on Peacock.

schema.headline: Sarah Snook Kidnapping Thriller â€˜All Her Faultâ€™ Is a Middling Entry in the Rich Mom Mystery Genre: TV Review

title: Longtime Soundgarden Manager Susan Silver on the Bandâ€™s Rock Hall of Fame Induction, Working With Alice in Chains, and Paving the Way for Female Executives (EXCLUSIVE)
description: In the fall of 1987, Ronald Reagan was president, Bon Jovi was the breakthrough band of the year, and mullets were still worn without irony by peopl
body:
In the fall of 1987, Ronald Reagan was president, Bon Jovi was the breakthrough band of the year, and mullets were still worn without irony by people who were not country musicians. Into that world dropped an orange-vinyl EP called â€œScreaming Lifeâ€ by a band named Soundgarden â€” from Seattle, of all places â€” that combined the then-disparate sounds of punk and hard rock in a way that no one had really done before. In many ways, that EP represented the birth of grunge. 
	

	It would be drastically reductive to say â€œthe rest is history,â€ but this week, Soundgarden will be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. 

	And after nearly 40 years of articles and books and documentaries and deluxe reissues and whatnot about the band and the scene, there is one key person whose story hasnâ€™t really been told: Susan Silver, who managed Soundgarden and Alice in Chains and Screaming Trees during their peak years of success and helped guide all three to the upper echelons of the music world.


	While Soundgardenâ€™s rise was not as meteoric as Nirvanaâ€™s or their longtime friends Pearl Jamâ€™s, thatâ€™s partially because they were, in many ways, the first ones from the scene over the wire: They were the first act to make a splash in New York, with a sweaty, smokey and jam-packed July 1988 show at CBGB; they were the first to sign with a major label; the first to make a big-budget video; and the first to undertake a major North American tour. They also may have been the first to score a gold record â€” but incredibly, Pearl Jamâ€™s â€œ10,â€ Nirvanaâ€™s â€œNevermindâ€ and Soundgardenâ€™s â€œBadmotorfingerâ€ were released in August, September and October of 1991 respectively, so whichever album first passed the 500,000-sales mark is all but impossible to call.
	

	It is no overstatement to say that the careers of Soundgarden, Alice and many other bands of the era would not have been what they were without Silver. She was not only one of the most important music managers of that era, but she is also one of the most important female managers in music history. This writer has known Silver since late 1987 and even then she showed a poise, professionalism and politeness that was rare, to say the least, for that brawny and undomesticated sector of the indie-rock scene.

	More importantly, Soundgarden themselves showed a level of discipline, focus and ambition beyond that of many peers, and their rise was intentionally measured and gradual: They released their first records on the then-small Seattle indie Sub Pop, then an album on legendary indie powerhouse SST, before releasing their major debut, â€œLouder Than Love,â€ on A&M in 1989. Over the next five years, Soundgarden, fronted by singer Chris Cornell, Silverâ€™s partner and later husband, became one of the biggest bands in the world. Alice in Chains, whom Silver also managed (and still does), were just a couple of years behind them and became just as big.



	

					Courtesy Jem Aswad
	



	â€œSusan came on board in â€˜86 or â€˜87, and for those next 10 years, she was very important,â€ Soundgarden guitarist Kim Thayil tells Variety. â€œWe had a pretty good knowledge of the music industry, but we didnâ€™t have the time or certainly the managerial skills to navigate that kind of world â€” we were probably a little more clumsy and blunt,â€ he laughs. â€œYou need someone who has that kind of skill, that kind of tact. Susan played it serious, and she played it smart; we read that in her and we trusted it. And we grew together â€” it could have been very problematic if weâ€™d had a more experienced manager, because we knew who we were and how we wanted to address the music community and industry, and a more experienced manager might have tried to tell us what to do and how we should do it, and we would have butted heads and wouldnâ€™t have worked.â€Â 

	A proud Seattle native, Silver had a hand in nearly every major landmark from the scene of the era: Cameron Croweâ€™s era-defining â€œSinglesâ€ film and blockbuster soundtrack album, early Lollapalooza tours, her bands touring with everyone from Guns Nâ€™ Roses to Van Halen before becoming arena-level headliners themselves. She even helped out a nascent Nirvana early in their career. 
	

	â€œFrom the first moment you meet her, you know Susan understands music and the creative fire of musicians like few others ever will,â€ Cameron Crowe tells Variety. â€œHer passion runs deep, as well as her guidance in what makes a great song or a great band truly timeless. Authenticity: That is SusanÂ Silver.â€

	Soundgarden and Alice were among the biggest bands of their generation â€”Â both have sold an estimated 30 million-plus albums worldwide â€” but as has been well documented, there was a tragic side as well: Alice in Chains singer Layne Staley died of a heroin overdose (in 2002 at the age of just 34) and Cornell passed away in 2017. Yet their legacy is formidable.

	â€œMeeting Susan and the band as a very young lawyer and having the honor of representing them changed my life forever,â€ says Universal Music Group EVP and former Soundgarden attorney Michele Anthony. â€œSusan was and still is the den mother of what was one of the most flourishing and important music communities of our generation. She embraced me into that pioneering community of musicians, just as it was on the verge of changing music and culture forever. Soundgarden, with Susan as their manager, helped define that change. That was also the beginning of our lifetime friendship.â€ 

	While always a fierce advocate for her artists, Silver has never been one to call attention to herself, and this interview literally was years in the making. Part of that is due to modesty on her part, but itâ€™s also due to her tough divorce from Cornell. Yet if there was ever a time to tell her story, itâ€™s now, as the band that she helped guide to superstardom is finally getting its moment, and she has the opportunity to share the wisdom from the challenges she overcame and the triumphs she witnessed as a woman â€” at a time when sexism was at a peak â€” in a still-male-dominated business. That wisdom is top of mind: She still manages Alice in Chains, who tour and record regularly, and Lily, her daughter with Cornell, is currently managing a band herself, the Seattle-based Americana outfit the Brudi Brothers.

	This interview has been edited and condensed from a two-hour conversation late last month.

	Did anything in your background prepare you for this career? What did your parents do for a living?
	

	My mother worked at Boeing during the [World War II] war effort in her early twenties â€” that was long before I came along â€” and then she worked some retail jobs as we as we got older. And my dad was the fourth pilot hired for Alaska Airlines, which gave us the opportunity to see all different parts of the world and instilled the travel bug in me.

	But I also had two little brothers. Theyâ€™re just two and four years younger than me, but they have very different personalities, and one in particular seemed to raise the ire of our father quite regularly. So I really honed some mediation skills, and I also mediated between my parents. 

	I do think those were fundamental experiences that helped me learn the importance of gaining trust from whoever it was that was looking to me for support or advice, the importance of being a good listener, providing critical feedback â€”Â and trying to make peace in non-peaceful times. In a family dynamic, of course, that had to be done in a compassionate way. By nature Iâ€™m pretty empathetic and observant, and thatâ€™s helped a lot.

	Did you have a musical background?

	I played piano and clarinet when I was growing up, but no, I didnâ€™t have that gene.Â 

	What did you initially want to do for a career?Â 

	When I was around 16 I was working at an art-supply store and had started volunteering in arts organizations, and I was able to see that creative people often arenâ€™t particularly organized. So I had what I thought was an original idea: that I could represent painters. Little did I know that had been going on for millennia, but it definitely jump-started the idea that I could be a useful force in creative peopleâ€™s lives.

	As I continued to volunteer for arts organizations in Seattle, everything from the opera to a science-fiction fair to Bumbershoot [music festival] in its early days, the calling became clearer and clearer â€” that creative people could benefit from having some modicum of organization and strategy and goals around them.

	Then everything unfolded in unexpected ways. I desperately tried to get a job at a nonprofit, and no matter how many times I nailed the interview and pressed the director with ideas, they just kept putting the carrot further and further out, and then eventually hired a family member â€” so I learned about that early on too. But as I try to [communicate] to the young people in my life, those disappointments are usually a detour to something better.
	

	And it certainly was: When I was in my early twenties, lo and behold, along came a band that needed a manager. My background was in the art world, but a band is still a group of creative people. They were a pop band called the First Thought, and soon that turned into helping out two bands â€” [proto-grunge outfit] the U-Men came along a couple of months later. So I was working out of the stock room of John Fluevog shoes, managing a couple of bands and helping people fit their shoes in between. I hope John doesnâ€™t ever read that!

	The First Thought made a record and did a tour down the West Coast, but the U-Men already had some history in Seattle, they had a record out on [influential indie label] Homestead, and the friend that was managing them got a full-time job and couldnâ€™t keep doing it. So I took over and booked my first couple of national tours using phone books from the library.



	

					Silver with Soundgarden (L-R: Matt Cameron, Kim Thayil, Hiro Yamamoto and Chris Cornell) and, top right, tour manager Eric â€œGunnyâ€ Johnson, 1988 (Courtesy Susan Silver)
	



	Did you have any business background?

	Iâ€™d taken some business courses in college and was still volunteering in the arts, but before I started managing those bands, I helped some people who opened an all-ages club called Metropolis that ended up being a very pivotal place in the genesis of the Seattle music scene. It was the most diverse array of artists imaginable: In one week youâ€™d have Jah Wobble, John Cale, the Violent Femmes and GBH, and the [local] musicians who played there went on to be in Soundgarden and Pearl Jam and Mudhoney.

	The club had two partners, and like my brothers, they were very different personalities, so I got to hone those mediating skills further, and I learned about booking and promoting. It was a really, really important part of my past.Â 

	I started promoting shows, and a year or two later, in 1985, I was at a life-changing Halloween party where a little power trio played called Soundgarden.

	Even though I was dressed up in drag that night â€” I was with my wonderful friend Hal Upchuck, who was quite an extraordinary performer, he had a beloved band called the F*gs and could dress like nobody else, and he dressed me up as him that night. So even though I looked like [Twisted Sister singer] Dee Snider, with a fright wig and the whole bit, the drummer of Soundgarden came up to me after they performed and said he recognized me from the vintage clothing store that I was working in at the time â€” where I did not dress like that, by the way. Little did I know that he had been repeatedly stopping in the store to quote-unquote shop, but later he told me he was really trying to work up the nerve to talk to me. So thatâ€™s how Chris and I met â€”Â at the time, he was the drummer and singer in Soundgarden.Â 
	

	By then Iâ€™d been promoting shows for some time, and also had started helping another seminal Seattle band called the Blackouts, so I told Chris I could take their bandâ€™s cassette to my promoter friends in Portland and Vancouver, where we would cross-promote shows a lot, and that conversation at that party led us to my great honor of managing Soundgarden, and the two of us being together for almost 20 years.

	What happened next?Â 

	Bruce Pavitt, who I knew because he had been a DJ at Metropolis, was starting a project called Sub Pop [which was originally a fanzine that also put out compilation cassettes] and he had a kind of subculture network that he would send music to. Around that time, â€™86-â€™87, Kim Thayil introduced Bruce to Jonathan Poneman, who was a musician but also had a very good business mind, and he thought Sub Pop could become a bona-fide record label. That became the next step for Soundgarden â€” I remember sitting on the floor at Bruceâ€™s apartment, boxing up records. Sub Pop started to take off, but the band had a different focus: They wanted to be on SST.Â 

	When do you feel like the band started to break out beyond the Northwest?

	Let me think for a secondâ€¦ I knew about the CMJ Music Marathon conference, and I said â€œThis is the sort of thing you guys should go to,â€ but not everybody wanted to. So Chris and I went â€” we found the â€œbestâ€ flight, which meant flying overnight from Seattle to Dallas to Chicago to New Jersey! We rolled in in the morning and went to the convention.

	Not only was that the first time he was on an airplane, but also his first time in New York, and the first time being in and around the music-business culture. I remember we were leaving the convention one day and waiting for a cab, and there was Ronnie James Dio standing on the sidewalk â€” it was a little bit like, Wow, these are more than just people in pictures and on records, theyâ€™re real!

	I think that began the reach-out into the world. The tours started shortly thereafter, just in our own cars, driving down the coast. Then once they signed with SST, they started getting better tours and signed with [longtime agent] Don Mueller, although it was still a good couple of years before they were playing on big stages.

	Things moved gradually, but they got very big, and neither you nor the band ever seemed intimidated by major labels or opening for Guns Nâ€™ Roses or anything like that.
	

	Soundgarden had a work ethic that really served them. They all had day jobs until touring made it impossible, and we were very, very conscientious about money. I mean, I had a little fund and I would write them $600-a-month paychecks. It was a â€œslow and steady wins the raceâ€ attitude and a really, really strong work ethic â€” not that the other bands here didnâ€™t also have one, but they might not have had perhaps the same crossover [potential], and the goals were different.

	Even though major labels were pursuing them fiercely, Soundgardenâ€™s goal was to be on SST. I remember the painful conversation with Jonathan [Poneman of Sub Pop], standing on the corner at the Pike Place Market, and him saying, â€œWe want to put out the next Soundgarden record, letâ€™s do this,â€ and having to say, â€œJonathan, youâ€™re a dear friend and I wish I could say that was going to happen. But this thing is a juggernaut, itâ€™s a rocket ship to who knows where, and they want to take the next step: They want to be on SST and then sign to a major.â€ They were very diligent about their steps â€” they didnâ€™t want to jump right to a major, like Alice in Chains did later.Â They very cautiously weighed their opportunities, but the ethos was still, â€œThereâ€™s no benefit in leaving our roots behind in one fell swoop.â€ They were extremely methodical about the steps they took.Â 

	The major label world at that time was very sexist â€” it still is. How did you deal with that?

	Well, I had some mentors, but letâ€™s preface that with the next major occurrence for me. 

	By 1988, I had set up an office with a fellow named Ken Deans who was running a production company. A man he knew asked him if we would consider working with a band that a guy named Randy was managing, â€œWeâ€™d love for you to come to the show, Randy has a surprise for everybody, theyâ€™re going to pick you upâ€ at 7 p.m. or whatever. And a limo pulled up â€” which was unheard of in Seattle, I donâ€™t even know if Iâ€™d ever seen a limo in Seattle. So I got in, with some trepidation, and met Alice in Chains for the first time.

	We drove to this venue, a 45-minute ride, and the whole time they were reciting, from beginning to end, the movie â€œFletch.â€ It was absolutely hilarious, I laughed the whole way, and then they put on a show that blew my mind and I listened to their cassette for the next four weeks. Eventually Randy dropped out of the picture and Ken decided he didnâ€™t want to be in the management business, so he asked his friend Kelly Curtis [later Pearl Jamâ€™s manager] and I if we would like to adopt Alice in Chains, and we did.
	

	Anyway, my first mentor, with Soundgarden, was [attorney] Peter Paterno. He helped me learn everything I needed to know about the record business and he shepherded the band through the various offers. The learning curve was steep, and he was incredibly patient and is one of the most wonderful humans on the planet. 

	So I brought Alice to him when Kelly and I started managing them and the record companies were showing strong interest. I was in his office one day and a woman walked by. Peter said, â€œHey Michele, come in here. I want to introduce you to Susan Silver â€” youâ€™re a chick, sheâ€™s a chick, and sheâ€™s managing a band with a chick name. Maybe you should work together.â€ And thatâ€™s how I met the amazing powerhouse, Michele Anthony.

	Michele took over as lead counsel for Alice, and we weighed through the various offers that they received and started to hone in on Columbia. She beat them senseless â€” so much so that as a signing gift, Alice gave her a pair of signed boxing gloves, which she still has in her office. And eventually [Columbia chiefs] Don Ienner and Tommy Mottola said, â€œWe donâ€™t ever want to be on the other side of the fence from you. Would you come and work with us?â€ Which is how she got to the label side of the business.Â 

	Peter re-adopted Alice [as attorney], and he is still their attorney to this day, and Michele became an incredible mentor and a dear, dear friend. She showed me how this can be done with strategy and a deep concern for the welfare of the artist â€” she was a very, very pro-artist attorney, certainly, but even as a label executive, she continued to fight for the artistâ€™s vision. And she taught me a lot about staying strong when you feel like youâ€™re being treated unfairly, whether it was the client being treated unfairly or where we as women were being not taken as seriously as we should have been â€” and also to just not believe [the unfair criticism].

	Then the next mentor that she introduced me to, Sharon Osborne, is also the personification of strength and grace. She gave me the confidence to keep moving forward with my career. Sheâ€™s really one of the most extraordinary people Iâ€™ve ever witnessed â€” in life and in business. Her ability to encompass and balance personal and business life, while remaining one of the fiercest negotiators the industry has ever seen, sets her in her own pantheon. 
	

	That was brought so strongly back to me this summer when I had the experience of being in Birmingham at â€œBack to the Beginningâ€ [the final Black Sabbath concert, last July]. Iâ€™ve been to a lot of events in my life, but none that radiated with such an incredible sense of love and community. I saw more misty eyes in leather jackets than I ever thought imaginable! And it was Sharon who set the tone and the directive for that incredible day.Â 

	But your approach is so different from hers. Iâ€™ve never even heard you raise your voice.Â 

	Well, I donâ€™t have the sort of profile that she or even Michele does, so the motto for me has always been to walk softly and carry a big stick â€” and as the ironies of life would have it, who do I end up having for management partners with Alice in Chains but Velvet Hammer [Management]?

	But I will fight for my client, and there are people who have received my ire if they go up against the ethos of what a band stands for. Iâ€™m thinking of one poor [major-label executive] with the Screaming Trees, when he started down a somewhat condescending path about how many records theyâ€™d be able to sell and how their idea of putting out vinyl, although quaint, was not going to happen â€”Â and he was saying it in front of [lead singer] Mark Lanegan, by the way. It was so inappropriate and I just felt so protective, and he needed to be schooled â€” he didnâ€™t understand, from a major-label perspective, where bands like Screaming Trees had come from. Soâ€¦ just put it this way: At the end of the day, they got the vinyl!

	Soundgarden and Alice in Chainsâ€™ rise to the top was almost in lockstep â€” the 1991 Clash of the Titans tour for Alice (with Slayer, Megadeth and Anthrax) and the 1991-92 Guns Nâ€™ Roses tour for Soundgarden pushed things to a whole other level.

	A whole other level. From â€™90 through â€™93 and even into the â€™94, it was nonstop. And donâ€™t forget, in January of â€™92 Nirvana knocked Michael Jackson out of the Billboard No. 1 slot, and there was the â€œSinglesâ€ film [which featured all three of the bands Silver managed], there was so much going on.Â 

	How did the bands cope with all that happening at once? Wasnâ€™t it overwhelming?

	At the time, it didnâ€™t feel overwhelming. Honestly, it felt â€¦
	

	Vindicating?

	No, no, there wasnâ€™t that energy at all. There was never that â€œWeâ€™ll show you!â€ vibe. It was more excitement, â€œWow, weâ€™re getting to do this!â€ and building every day, building, building, building. People talk about it being an overnight success, but it wasnâ€™t. I started in the early â€˜80s and this was almost a decade later. With a band like Alice, they just wanted to be out there playing, they were born for this. 

	With Soundgarden, there was a little more pacing needed because they, as I mentioned, did things very methodically andâ€¦ what some people would assume are the alluring parts of life on the road were not of interest to them. That was not who Soundgarden was; they did not fall under â€œsex, drugs, and rock and roll.â€ It was about work and playing great shows and seeing other bands that they loved get opportunities.

	I remember listening to Kim try to convince the head of A&M to sign [Seattle band] Presidents of the United States of America, like, â€œYou donâ€™t understand, these guys are amazing! Youâ€™ve got to give them a listen!â€ And they ended up going somewhere else and becoming very successful. [The bandâ€™s 1995 debut album went triple platinum.]

	I remember Chris as a pretty shy person. How did he deal with all the attention and becoming the iconic rock god that people made him out to be?Â 

	Chris was very private, thatâ€™s something we shared. We were both shy kids and shy growing up, and as he grew into the incredible singer and performer that he became, I think he had to put a sort of invisible shield around himself because he was very, very sensitive to external energy. He wasnâ€™t the guy to sit around and read reviews or listen to peopleâ€™s opinions about his band or about his performance â€” and he hated gossip. So I think it was more as a sort of eyes-down, walk straight ahead, put that invisible force field around himself. And that often could be interpreted as arrogance, but really it was shyness and being a very sensitive person â€” and a necessary self-defense.

	Because as weâ€™ve seen, this business, the industry and the fans themselves, will chew an artist up and spit them out. And with the onset of instant information, itâ€™s almost like we as a people have somehow demonstrated this sort of lower vibration of feeling better about ourselves when we see other people fail. I feel so lucky for myself and for my clients that they had this success before the digital age.
	



	

					Silver with Alice in Chains, circa 1994 (Courtesy Susan Silver)
	



	So now weâ€™re up to 1994 and â€™95. We know what happened with Alice, but when did it feel like Soundgarden was starting to break up?Â 

	â€œDown on the Upsideâ€ [released in 1996, the bandâ€™s final album until 2010] was a tough record to make. I think they started to be of different minds creatively. And with success comes a pressure that doesnâ€™t get discussed enough. There are incredible upsides to success that are very obvious, but there also comes a payoff in not only a lack of privacy, but sometimes in real physical threats â€” not only externally but internally. So we often see people second-guessing themselves: â€œHow did this happen so fast? Where am I going? Have I done the right thing?â€ Thereâ€™s a momentum in it, and then itâ€™s really, really hard to get off the gerbil wheel.

	It can cause some real mental suffering. When young people have that kind of success â€” and certainly money is an element in it â€” that access becomes problematic if the person has any sort of mental-health issues. Self-medicating becomes an avenue that a lot of people take, thinking it will help them make sense of it, and as weâ€™ve all seen, itâ€™s even encouraged. The access is there.

	You mean access to things that are not healthy?Â 

	Yeah, accesses that lead to substance abuse, but thereâ€™s also access in terms of â€¦ thereâ€™s a world in which doors open. There are people who are paid to do things for successful people, not exclusively musicians but also actors, executives, athletes. Thereâ€™s an access that starts to create a different set of expectations, and if not monitored, can turn into entitlement â€” which I think is one of the greatest core-rotters there is, when people start to demonstrate entitled behavior. Itâ€™s as hard to recover from as narcissism.

	Success can breed that, it can breed all of those ills. We all have dark sides of our unconscious minds, and it takes a lot of self-awareness and self-actualization to check our behaviors and ask the deep questions: â€œAm I on track?â€ And sometimes the route becomes substance abuse, sometimes it becomes abuse of the people closest to us. And sadly more times than not, Iâ€™ve seen successful people lose the plot, and then their world just becomes other successful people, and theyâ€™re in this bubble that is missing a healthy dose of reality. Theyâ€™ll step out of it once in awhile to do some charity work or something, and then go right back into it.
	

	I get it, because itâ€™s safe being around people who know what youâ€™re going through. But at the same time, if not monitored, can become destructive.Â 

	Is that what happened?Â 

	To Chris?

	To any of them.Â 

	Oh, itâ€™s happened to many, many of the musicians that I watched as my professional life grew. And some it hasnâ€™t, and theyâ€™re wonderful. But thereâ€™s a price that gets paid at the crossroads for success, and it just takes it takes a lot of introspection to not fall into it irretrievably.Â 

	This all deserves someone smarter than me doing a dissertation or a well-funded scientific study. But, you know, idol worship isâ€¦ well, we all know where it leads.

	Just bringing it back to your career, did you stop managing at any point?Â 

	No. After Soundgarden disbanded in â€™97 and Alice was in their dormant period â€” they never broke up â€” people just assumed that I wasnâ€™t managing, but I was doing administrative management for both bands. I managed Alice the whole time and still do, and Soundgarden up until 2010, when they got back together. Chris and I were divorced by then, and Alice was active and I was really back full-time with them, and it made sense for [Soundgarden] to be under a management umbrella with Chris.

	Werenâ€™t you also raising your daughter at that point?Â 

	Yes, that was my main focus. From the time that Soundgarden disbanded, my main focus was bringing Lily into the world. And then, sadly, Chris and I parted when she was two. So yeah, I had some understandably quiet years. But then, in 2005, when Lily was almost five, Alice put on whatâ€™s known as the â€œtsunami show.â€

	After the Indonesian tsunami in December of 2004, Sean Kinney [Alice in Chains drummer], who is one of the most caring human beings on the planet, was just devastated by what he was seeing on the news and said, â€œWe have to do something.â€ Thatâ€™s how the tsunami benefit came together [where Alice in Chainsâ€™ surviving bandmembers performed together for the first time in six years, with guest vocalists including Toolâ€™s Maynard James Keenan filling in for Staley], and it was such a profound experience.

	A few months later, [AIC guitarist/singer Jerry Cantrell] and Sean called and said, â€œWe want to do this again.â€ I was really focused on my daughter and getting through a very painful divorce, and I said, â€œIâ€™m really happy for you guys, youâ€™re not too old, go for it.â€
	

	But Sean said, â€œI said we are going to go out and do it one more time. Thatâ€™s you and us. Weâ€™re not doing it without you.â€

	And I swear to you, after all the therapy and soul retrievals and praying that I had been doing to put my heart together over the previous few years, it was like all the disparate pieces came back together. I had been given such an incredible gift, and of course initially I started to backpedal and came up with a million reasons why I couldnâ€™t do it. And they just said, â€œWeâ€™re not doing it without you. Youâ€™re coming with us.â€

	So by the end of the year, they had brought [current singer] William Duvall into the mix, and they had to do the slow build in the club scene. At first, I couldnâ€™t get them arrested. Iâ€™d call people and say, â€œThey would love to perform at your benefitâ€ and Iâ€™d hear, â€œYeah, call us later, bye!,â€ laughing. But it built slowly, 2006, 2007, and by 2010 they were headlining Madison Square Garden. That was a very satisfying and solidifying experience for all of us. It changed the dynamic of my relationship with them, certainly.

	Management is often considered the parental figure in a bandâ€™s life, and I can understand that, but we had been through so much together. Certainly the loss of Layne and, shortly after, the loss of [bassist] Mike Starr, and all of the substance abuse that they had been through and the subsequent sobriety. So by the time they started working again, our dynamic had changed to one of a very familial partnership. Iâ€™d work for free for those guys for the rest of my life if they wanted. They really gave me my life back.

	Wasnâ€™t it hard to do that as a single mom?Â 

	It was incredibly hard to get back into business mode as a single mom. There is no greater hero in this world than a single mom. It is the hardest job, hands down, Iâ€™ve ever done and that Iâ€™ve ever witnessed. Teachers are right up there as unsung heroes, but itâ€™s really, really painful to leave your leave your child and go on a business trip. Your brain and your heart get split in two different directions. 

	But at the same time, it has provided a life for us and a sense of purpose for me â€” not that being a parent isnâ€™t one of lifeâ€™s great purposes, if not the greatest. And I had amazing people around me, including Chrisâ€™s family, who are our lifeblood and our stability, mine and Lilyâ€™s, they have been absolutely incredible and are to this day. But it was difficult, for sure.Â 
	

	Are you managing any other acts right now?Â 

	I am only managing Alice and I currently have the good fortune of acting as, call it guidance counselor or consigliere, for the Brudi Brothers.Â 

	One of the other things I do is volunteer at a music and film youth camp that also has a young entrepreneur division called Prodigy Camp. Thereâ€™s a twofold path: Helping to support young people, 13 to 19 years old, as they face and think about their lifeâ€™s most difficult times, and then helping them to transform that into film or music. Iâ€™ve been with them for five years, and watching some of these young people navigate really hard circumstances into solid careers in film and in music has been one of lifeâ€™s great satisfactions. They create an incredibly collaborative environment between the Campers and the mentors â€” the mentors are industry professionals like me, and theyâ€™re also returning Campers.

	One of the original Campers who has come back for 10 years to mentor is Chappell Roan.Â For her to be there in the midst of all of her wild success is a testament of the camp and to her.

	As we were saying earlier about how people cope with fame and attention: She has the foundation to say what she needs with vulnerability, honesty and strength. I admire her so much for how sheâ€™s handling it all.

	How is your daughterâ€™s career as a music manager going?

	Itâ€™s going well. The Brudi Brothers came out of the box with basically no road experience, and there was a feeding frenzy a la â€˜80s Seattle. But they wisely â€” and intuitively, I think â€” picked [New York-based indie label] Mom + Pop, who have given them a lot of space as well as a tremendous amount of support. So theyâ€™ve really been growing and working this year, and got some great tours. Theyâ€™ve been out with Sierra Farrell a few times, did some Charlie Crockett shows, another little tour with Wyatt Flores, so itâ€™s been really fun to watch them grow.

	Top-of-mind, what advice would you have for young female managers or executives who are trying to get into the business?

	Stay the course.Â Double-check your work, because somebody else will be double-checking it. Donâ€™t give anybody a reason to think youâ€™re not 1,000% capable. Keep emotions out of the business dealings and out of the interactions with the clients. Suit up, show up, and do good work, and your work will speak for itself.Â 
	

	And you have to care about what youâ€™re doing â€” thatâ€™s the other thing. A lot of musicians who become public figures, they almost donâ€™t have a choice; theyâ€™re driven internally by some North Star. Itâ€™s the same in business. You have to want it so badly that youâ€™re willing to do it for free, to put in the hours to go above and beyond.

	I donâ€™t think the world has changed radically in terms of being male-dominated, but certainly weâ€™re making inroads. We could get into a deep philosophical conversation about the â€œlast swing of the patriarchyâ€ and all of that, but really, you know, old habits die hard. You look at countries where there are, for example, female prime ministers, and it works just fine. So the United States is a little behind in both politics and business, but weâ€™re making progress. I had incredible mentors that helped open doors for me and encouraged me to just keep doing good work.

	Last question: How does it feel to see Soundgarden going into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame?Â 

	Iâ€™m so proud of them. So proud of them. Itâ€™s so deserved, so well-earned, Iâ€™m absolutely thrilled and excited to be there with them, to see them perform, to see the surprises they have in store.

	It wouldnâ€™t have happened, at least not in this way, without you.Â 

	(Through slightly gritted teeth.) And it wouldnâ€™t have happened without me (laughing).

	You actually said it!

	(Still laughing) Iâ€™m trying! Iâ€™m really trying to look at this with some inclusion for myself, which is why Iâ€™m talking with you today. We get reflective at this stage in life, especially as the losses mount, and I have to say again, Sharon did it with â€œBack to the Beginning.â€ I left that event feeling more alive, purposeful, excited about the future than I can remember feeling in decades. 

	I remember standing in the front with [Alice in Chains bassist] Mike Inezâ€™s wife, Sydney, while Mike played bass with Ozzy for those five songs. Ozzy was so powerful, and when he started singing â€œMama, Iâ€™m Coming Home,â€ it was an otherworldly experience. His voice changed, his features changed, the audience got quiet and I could feel the tears coming. Then the audience started singing and finished that song for him, and he had tears streaming down his face.

	There have been a lot of reasons to reflect lately, and seeing this next generation take over has been a big part of it for me, whether itâ€™s Chappell or the Brudi Brothers. Itâ€™s torch-passing time, and Iâ€™m thrilled to see yet another Seattle group carve out a place in yet another genre of music. I continue to be super, super proud of Seattle.

schema.headline: Longtime Soundgarden Manager Susan Silver on the Bandâ€™s Rock Hall of Fame Induction, Working With Alice in Chains, and Paving the Way for Female Executives (EXCLUSIVE)

title: Nurse Who Killed 10 Patients to Lighten His Workload Gets Life in Prison
description:
Killer Nurse
                          I Had Too Much Work ...
                          So I Wha
body:
Killer Nurse
                          I Had Too Much Work ...
                          So I Whacked My Patients!!!
                      
                  
                        Published November 6, 2025 6:31 AM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 6, 2025 7:47 AM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          A nurse in Germany came up with a novel way to lighten his workload ... he reportedly murdered 10 of his patients.
      
    
          The nurse, whose name was not released, was given a life sentence in prison Wednesday after he was convicted of murdering all 10 patients by lethal injection, and attempting to kill 27 more, according to CNN.
      
    
          During the trial, prosecutors accused the nurse of trying to cut his evening workload by giving his mostly geriatric patients doses of painkillers and sedatives in a hospital near the German city of Aachen, CNN said.
      

          Despite his life term, by law, the nurse could be released from prison after serving a minimum of 15 years ... but that's highly unlikely because of the severity of the crimes, according to a spokesperson for the Aachen court. The nurse can appeal his verdict.
      
    
          And get this ... German media outlets report ... police are investigating other suspicious incidents involving the nurse during his career.

title: 'Will & Grace' Star Eric McCormack Settles Divorce
description:
'Will & Grace' Star Eric McCormack
                          Settles Divorce
body:
'Will & Grace' Star Eric McCormack
                          Settles Divorce
                      
                  
                        Published November 6, 2025 7:13 AM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 6, 2025 7:48 AM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Eric McCormack and his estranged wife Janet Holden have settled their divorce ... TMZ has learned.
      
    
          As we reported ... Janet was the one who pulled the plug two years ago, filing for divorce after more than 26 years of marriage with the "Will & Grace" star.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          At the time, Janet was seeking spousal support and looking to end the court's ability to award Eric spousal support.
      

          While Eric says the parties have entered into a written agreement regarding their property and any spousal support, the details of the deal are still under wraps. Â All that's left is for the judge to sign off on the settlement.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Eric and Janet first met in 1994 on the set of the "Lonesome Dove" TV show ... where he was an actor and she was the assistant director. They got hitched in August 1997. They share one son together -- Finnigan -- who is 23.

title: Former Memphis Grizzlies Star Tony Allen Arrested on Drug Charges in Arkansas
description:
Ex-NBA Star Tony Allen
                          Busted On Drug Charges
body:
Ex-NBA Star Tony Allen
                          Busted On Drug Charges
                      
                  
                        Published November 6, 2025 5:28 AM PST
                                                                      |
                Updated November 6, 2025 7:22 AM PST
                                    
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Tony Allen -- a former star and lockdown defender for the Memphis Grizzlies -- is locked up behind bars in Arkansas on drug charges ... TMZ has learned.
      
    
          The Poinsett County Sheriff's Office tells TMZ ... Allen is facing two charges of drug possession -- one felony and one misdemeanor -- and he's currently being held without bond.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          Poinsett County Sheriff Kevin Molder tells TMZ ... Allen was riding as a passenger in a vehicle that was pulled over after the driver improperly changed lanes on an interstate about 50 miles from Memphis.
      

          Authorities say Allen was found with a bag of marijuana on him ... and when deputies searched the vehicle, they allegedly found cocaine in a cigarette box.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                                  
      
    
          Allen later posed for a mug shot in a white T-shirt ... and based on his expression, he's not thrilled about it.
      
    
          The 43-year-old was a staple on the Grizzlies from 2011 to 2017, and also played for the Boston Celtics and New Orleans Pelicans. His jersey was retired by the Grizzlies in March -- and he's widely considered one of the best defensive players of all time.
      
    
                  
          
                          
                
                  
      
    
          This isn't the first time Allen's been in trouble with the law ... in 2023, he pled guilty in a federal case involving an NBA health insurance and fraud scheme -- and was sentenced to community service and three years of supervised probation.
      
      
              
          
                          
                TMZ Sports

schema.headline: Former Memphis Grizzlies Star Tony Allen Arrested on Drug Charges in Arkansas
